“He told me specifically he was not working for the Russian government, and in fact laughed when I asked him that question.”

Akhmetshin was the subject of a letter that Sen. Chuck Grassley (R-Iowa), chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee, sent to Homeland Security Secretary John Kelly in April as part of an investigation into potential violations committed by the lobbyist under the Foreign Agents Registration Act.

Trump Jr.'s attorney tells @NBCNews he thought additional person in lawyer meeting was friend of intermediary https://t.co/yKT7rLob3y — NBC News (@NBCNews) July 14, 2017

U.S. officials are examining Akhmetshin’s involvement in the 2016 meeting as part of their larger investigation into potential links between the Kremlin and Trump campaign associates, Politico reported Friday.

Trump Jr.’s attorney, Alan Futerfas, told NBC News on Friday that his client hadn’t been aware of the lobbyist’s background at the time of the meeting and had believed the individual was simply a friend of the intermediary who set up the meeting.

He also cited a Radio Free Europe report that described the operative as a “Russian gun-for-hire.”

Akhmetshin told the AP that he served in the Soviet army from 1986 to 1988, but denied ever receiving counterintelligence training.

The revelation of at least two additional meeting attendees appears to contradict Trump Jr.’s recent comments, as he claimed he’s been totally transparent about the meeting and said all relevant information had been reported.

Hours later, CNN reported that at least eight people may have attended the meeting, including publicist Rob Gladstone, an interpreter, and a representative for a Russian family who had asked Gladstone to set up the meeting.

Rinat Akhmetshin participated in the meeting, he confirmed to The Associated Press on Friday after NBC News first reported that a Russian-American lobbyist was present when Trump Jr. met with Natalia Veselnitskaya.

Jared Kushner, Trump’s son-in-law and current presidential adviser, and Paul Manafort, Trump’s campaign manager at the time, also attended the meeting held June 9, 2016, at Trump Tower in New York City.
A Russian-American lobbyist, who is also a former Soviet military officer, was in the room during a June 2016 meeting between Donald Trump Jr. and a Russian lawyer, according to multiple reports.
Akhmetshin told AP that he believed Veselnitskaya left documents with Trump Jr. and his associates that detailed what she said was the flow of unlawful funds to the Democratic National Committee.
When Veselnitskaya told Trump Jr. that his associates would need to conduct more research to prove the connection, the president’s son became less engaged in the meeting, according to Akhmetshin.
Veselnitskaya, who was described as a “Russian government attorney” in the email chain, revealed earlier this week that a man had accompanied her to the meeting.
Sen. Dick Durbin (D-Ill.) described the NBC News report as the latest detail in a “slow bleed” of information related to Trump Jr.’s meeting with Veselnitskaya.
In a recently surfaced email chain before the meeting, President Donald Trump’s eldest son was promised a meeting with a Kremlin-linked lawyer.
The president’s son accepted the offer, saying he would “love” to receive compromising information on his father’s political opponent.
Dmitry Peskov, a spokesman for Russian President Vladimir Putin, appeared to refute Akhmetshin’s alleged connection to the Kremlin.
In the letter, Grassley wrote that Akhmetshin had admitted to being a former Soviet counterintelligence officer.
“Basic rules in Washington: It’s not the crime; it’s the coverup,” Durbin told MSNBC’s “Morning Joe” on Friday.
NBC News reported that several U.S. officials believe the lobbyist has ongoing ties to the Kremlin.
Trump Jr. was told the lawyer had dirt on then-Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton.
Futerfas also revealed that another unnamed person, in addition to Trump’s team, was present.
“I never thought this would be such a big deal, to be honest,” Akhmetshin told the AP.
The New York Times has since identified the interpreter as Anatoli Samochornov.
“This is everything,” Trump Jr. told Fox News’ Sean Hannity on Tuesday.
“He is a U.S. citizen,” Futerfas told NBC News of the lobbyist.
“We don’t know anything about this person,” Peskov told the AP.
It’s unclear if Russian government provided the documents.
“Secondly, when you make a disclosure, make it complete.”
Futerfas did not identify that person or the lobbyist.
Akhmetshin has denied the accusation.
She did not identify him.
